text: There once was a man in the land of Uz named Job. The man was blameless as well as upright. He feared God and kept away from evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seven sons and three daughters had been born to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: His livestock included 7,000 sheep, 3,000 camels, 500 teams of oxen, 500 female donkeys, and many servants. Indeed, the man’s stature greatly exceeded that of many people who lived in the East.
speaker: Narrator

text: His sons used to travel to each other’s houses in turn on a regular schedule and hold festivals, inviting their three sisters to celebrate with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When their time of feasting had concluded, Job would rise early in the morning to send for them and consecrate them to God. He would offer a burnt offering for each one, because Job thought, “Perhaps my children sinned by cursing God in their hearts.” Job did this time and again.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day, divine beings presented themselves to the Lord, and Satan accompanied them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord asked Satan, “Where have you come from?”
In response, Satan answered the Lord, “From wandering all over the earth and walking back and forth throughout it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord asked Satan, “Have you considered my servant Job? There is no one like him on earth. The man is blameless as well as upright. He fears God and keeps away from evil.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But in response, Satan asked the Lord, “Does Job fear God for nothing?
speaker: Narrator

text: Haven’t you surrounded him with a fence on all sides, around his house, and around all that he owns? You have blessed everything he puts his hands on and you have increased his livestock in the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, stretch out your hand and strike everything he owns, and he will curse you to your face.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord told Satan, “Very well then, everything he owns is under your control, only you may not extend your hand against him.” So Satan left the Lord’s presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some time later, when his children were celebrating in their oldest brother’s house,
speaker: Narrator

text: a messenger approached Job and said, “The oxen were plowing and the female donkeys were grazing nearby
speaker: Narrator

text: when the Sabeans attacked, captured the servants, and killed them with swords. I alone escaped to tell you!”
speaker: Narrator

text: While this messenger was still speaking, another came and announced, “A lightning storm struck and incinerated the flock and the servants while they were eating. I alone escaped to tell you!”
speaker: Narrator

text: While this messenger was still speaking, another came and announced, “The Chaldeans formed three companies, raided the camels, captured the servants, and killed them with swords. Only I alone escaped to tell you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: While this messenger was still speaking, another came and announced, “Your children were celebrating in their oldest brother’s house
speaker: Narrator

text: when a strong wind came straight out of the wilderness and struck the four corners of the house. It collapsed on the young people, and they died. I alone escaped to tell you!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job stood up, tore his robe, shaved his head, fell to the ground, bowed very low,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and exclaimed:
“I left my mother’s womb naked,
    and I will return to God naked.
The Lord has given,
    and the Lord has taken.
        May the name of the Lord be blessed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Job neither sinned nor charged God with wrongdoing in all of this.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some time later, divine beings again presented themselves to the Lord, and Satan accompanied them to present himself to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord asked Satan, “Where have you come from?”
In response, Satan told the Lord, “From wandering all over the earth and walking back and forth throughout it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord asked Satan, “Have you considered my servant Job? There is no one like him on earth. The man is blameless as well as upright. He fears God and keeps away from evil. He remains firm in his integrity, even though you have been urging me to overwhelm him without cause.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Satan answered the Lord, “Skin for skin! The man will give up everything that he owns in exchange for his health.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, stretch out your hand and strike his bones and flesh, and he’ll curse you to your face, won’t he?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord told Satan, “Very well then, he is under your control. Just preserve his life.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Satan left the Lord’s presence and struck Job with terrible boils from the sole of his feet to the top of his head.
speaker: Narrator

text: Job took a broken piece of pottery to scrape himself while sitting among the ashes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then his wife told him, “Do you remain firm in your integrity? Curse God and die!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But he replied to her, “You’re talking like foolish women do. Are we to accept what is good from God but not tragedy?”
Throughout all of this, Job did not sin by what he said.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Job’s three friends heard all these tragedies that happened to him, they each traveled from their home towns to visit him. Eliphaz came from Teman, Bildad came from Shuah, and Zophar came from Naamath. They met together and went to console and comfort him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Observing him from a distance, at first they didn’t even recognize him, so they raised their voices and burst into tears. They each ripped their robes, threw ashes into the air on their heads,
speaker: Narrator

text: and sat with Job on the ground for a full week without saying a word, since they could see the great extent of his anguish.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, Job spoke up solemnly, cursing the day he was born.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what Job said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Let the day when I was born be annihilated,
    along with the night when it was announced,
        ‘It’s a boy!’
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
“Yes, let that night be barren;
    let it not appear with its joyful shout.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let whoever curses days curse it—
    those who are ready to awaken monsters.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“Because that night refused to shut the doors of my mother’s womb;
    it failed to keep me from seeing this trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why didn’t I die while I was still in the womb,
    or die while I was being born?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why was there a lap to hold me,
    and why were there breasts to nurse me?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If I had died, I would be lying down by now,
    undisturbed, asleep, and at rest,
speaker: Narrator

text:
along with kings and counselors of the earth,
    who used to build for themselves what are now only ruins,
speaker: Narrator

text:
or princes who amassed gold for themselves,
    and who kept filling their houses with silver.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Or why was I not buried like a stillborn child,
    like babies who never saw the light?
speaker: Narrator

text:
In that place, the wicked stop causing trouble,
    and there, those whose strength is exhausted are at rest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In that place, those who once were prisoners will be at ease together;
    they won’t hear the voice of oppressors.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The unimportant and the important are both there,
    and the servant is free from his master.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Why does God give light to the sufferer
    or life to the bitter person:
speaker: Narrator

text:
To those who are longing for death—
    even though it does not come?
To those who search for it
    more than for hidden treasure?
speaker: Narrator

text:
To those who are happy beyond measure
    when they reach their graves?
speaker: Narrator

text:
To the formerly successful man who lost his way in life,
    and God fenced him in?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“As far as I’m concerned, my food comes to me in the form of sighs,
    and my cries of anguish pour out like water.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the dreaded thing that I feared has happened to me,
    what caused me to worry has engulfed me.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: In reply, Eliphaz from Teman answered:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Will you get offended if somebody tries to talk to you?
    Who can keep from speaking at a time like this?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look! You’ve admonished many people,
    and you’ve strengthened feeble hands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A word from you has supported those who have stumbled,
    and has strengthened faltering knees.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But now it’s your turn,
    and you’re the one who is worn out!
Now it’s striking you,
    and you’re dismayed!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Your fear of God has been your confidence, hasn’t it?
    The integrity of your life has been your hope, hasn’t it?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now please think:
    Who has ever perished when they’re innocent?
        Where have the upright been destroyed?
speaker: Narrator

text:
It’s been my experience that those who plow the soil of iniquity
    and those who sow the seed of trouble will reap their harvest!
speaker: Narrator

text:
They perish by the breath of God;
    they are consumed by the storm that is his anger.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Full grown lions die when they cannot find prey;
    that’s when the lion cubs are scattered.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“A message was confided to me;
    my ear caught a whisper of it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Disquieting thoughts from dreams at night;
    when deep sleep falls on everyone.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A fear fell upon me, along with trembling
    that caused all my bones to shake in terror.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A spirit glided past me
    and made the hair on my skin to bristle.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It remained standing,
    but I couldn’t recognize its appearance.
A form appeared before my eyes;
    At first there was silence, and then this voice:
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Can a mortal person be more righteous than God?
    Or can the purity of the valiant exceed that of his maker?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Indeed, since he doesn’t trust his servants,
    since he charges his angels with error,
speaker: Narrator

text:
how much less confidence does he have
    in those who dwell in houses of clay;
who were formed from a foundation in dust
    and can perish like a moth?
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are defeated between morning and evening;
    they perish forever—and no one notices!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their wealth perishes with them, doesn’t it?
    They die, and do so without having wisdom, don’t they?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Cry out, won’t you!
    Is there anyone who will answer you?
        To whom will you turn among the holy ones?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For wrath will slay a fool;
    zealous anger will kill the naïve.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I myself saw a fool becoming established,
    but I suddenly cursed where he lived.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Then the hungry will devour his harvest,
    snatching it even from the midst of thorns,
        while the thirsty covet their wealth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For wickedness doesn’t crop up from dust,
    nor does trouble sprout out of the ground;
speaker: Narrator

text:
But mankind is born headed for trouble,
    just as sparks soar skyward.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Now as for me, I would seek God if I were you;
    I would commit my case to God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He is always doing great things that cannot be explained,
    countless awesome deeds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He sends rain on the surface of the earth,
    and waters the surface of the open country.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He sets the lowly on high,
    and lifts those who mourn to safety.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He frustrates the plans of the crafty;
    so that what they work for never succeeds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He captures the wise in their own craftiness,
    bringing a quick end to their cunning advice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They meet with darkness in broad daylight;
    at noonday they grope around as if it were night.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So he delivers from the sword of their mouth—
    the poor from the power of the mighty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore there is hope for those who are poor,
    and iniquity shuts its mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Indeed, how blessed is the person whom God reproves!
    So never disrespect the discipline of the Almighty,
speaker: Narrator

text:
because though he wounds, but then applies bandages;
    though he strikes, his hands still heal.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“He will deliver you through six calamities;
    and calamity won’t touch you throughout the seventh.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will deliver you from death by famine;
    in war from the power of the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You’ll be protected from the accusing tongue;
    you need not fear destruction when it heads your way.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You’ll laugh at destruction and famine;
    and you need not fear the beasts of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For you’ll have a pact with the stones in the field;
    and the beasts of the field will be at peace with you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You’ll know that your home is secure;
    when you search your possessions, and nothing will be missing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You’ll know that you’ll have many children;
    and that your offspring will be like the grass of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You’ll go to your grave at a ripe old age;
    like a stack of grain that’s harvested at just the right time.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: In rebuttal, Job replied:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If only my grief could be weighed;
    or my calamity piled together on a balance scale!
speaker: Narrator

text:
It would weigh more than the sand on the seashore!
    Here’s why I’ve talked so rashly:
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“Will the wild donkey bray from hunger if fresh grass is beside him?
    Will the ox low from distress if it is near its feed?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Tasteless food isn’t eaten without salt, is it?
    Is there any taste in an egg white?
speaker: Narrator

text:
I cannot bring myself to touch them;
    food like this makes me sick.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Who will grant my wish?
    I wish God would grant what I’m hoping for:
speaker: Narrator

text:
that God would just be willing to crush me;
    that he would let loose and eliminate me!
speaker: Narrator

text:
At least I could still take comfort
    and rejoice in unceasing anguish,
        for I didn’t conceal what the Holy One has to say.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Do I have the strength to wait?
    And why should I be patient?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Am I as strong as a rock?
    Am I some kind of iron man?
speaker: Narrator

text:
There is no help within me, is there?
    My resources have been driven away from me, haven’t they?
speaker: Narrator

text:
The friend shows gracious love for his friend,
    even if he has forsaken the fear of the Almighty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But my brothers have acted treacherously like a cascading river,
    like torrential rivers that overflow.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Filled with waters made cold by ice,
    they are where the snow goes to hide.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But then the snow melts, and they disappear;
    when warmed, they evaporate from their stream beds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Travelers divert in their route;
    they go into a wasteland and die.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Travelers from Tema search intently;
    caravans from Sheba hope to find them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For all their expectations, they are doomed to disappointment;
    even though they have come and searched this far.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“And now you’re all just like them, aren’t you?
    You see my terror and are terrified.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When did I ever ask you for anything,
    say ‘Offer a bribe for me from your wealth?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
or say ‘Deliver me from my enemy’s control,’
    or ‘Redeem me from the domination of ruthless people’?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Instruct me, and I’ll remain silent.
    Help me understand where I’ve gone astray.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The truth can be painful,
    but what has your argument proven?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Did you intend your words to reprove,
    even though the speech of a desperate person is just wind?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, you would gamble to buy an orphan;
    and barter to buy your friend!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now be willing to face me,
    and I won’t lie to your face.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Repent! Let there be no injustice;
    Change your ways! My vindication is at stake.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have I said anything that’s unjust?
    I can discern evil, can’t I?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Men have harsh servitude on earth, do they not?
    His days are like those of a hired laborer, are they not?
speaker: Narrator

text:
I’m like a servant who longs for the shade,
    like a hired laborer who is looking for his wages.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Truly I’ve been allotted months of emptiness;
    nights of trouble have been appointed for me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“When I lie down I ask,
    ‘When will I wake up?’
But the night continues
    and I keep tossing and turning until dawn.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My skin is covered with worms and clods of dirt;
    my skin becomes rough and then breaks out afresh.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My days pass as swiftly as a hand-loom;
    they come to their conclusion without hope.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Remember that my life is a breath;
    my eyes won’t go back to seeing good things.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
As a cloud fades away and vanishes,
    the one who descends to the afterlife doesn’t return.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He doesn’t return again to his house,
    and his place won’t recognize him anymore.”
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Am I the sea, or a sea monster,
    that you keep watching me?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For I’ve said, ‘My bed will comfort me;
    my couch will ease my burdens while I complain.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
But then you scared me with dreams;
    you terrified me with visions.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I would rather die by strangulation
    than continue living.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I hate the thought of living forever!
    Leave me alone, because my days are pointless.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“What is a human being, that you make so much of him;
    that you set your affections on him,
speaker: Narrator

text:
visit him every morning,
    and test him continually?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why won’t you look away from me?
    Why don’t you leave me alone so I can swallow my saliva?
speaker: Narrator

text:
So what if I sin? What have I done against you,
    you observer of humankind?
Why have you made me your target?
    Why burden yourself with me?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why haven’t you pardoned my transgression
    and taken away my iniquity?
Now I’m about to lie down in the dust.
    You will seek me diligently,
        but I won’t be around!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then in response, Bildad from Shuah said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“How long will you keep talking like this?
    How long will you keep talking like a wind storm?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Does God pervert justice?
    Does the Almighty pervert what’s right?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If your children sin against him,
    he’ll make them a prisoner of their sins.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you seek God,
    if you ask the Almighty for mercy,
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Your beginning may be small,
    but later years will be very great.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Inquire of the previous generation, won’t you please?
    Consider what their forefathers searched out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Because we are of yesterday and we know nothing,
    for our time on earth is only a shadow.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Won’t they instruct you, and tell you,
    and bring out words from the heart?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Can papyrus grow where there’s no marsh?
    Can reeds flourish without water?
speaker: Narrator

text:
While they are still green
    and not yet ready to be harvested,
        they wither before any plant.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Such are the paths of everyone who forgets God—
    the hope of the godless will be destroyed:
speaker: Narrator

text:
his confidence is shattered;
    his trust is in a spider’s web.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He leans against his house,
    but it won’t stand;
he grabs hold of it firmly,
    but it doesn’t last.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He is a fresh sapling planted in the sunlight,
    spreading out its branches over its garden.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Its roots weave around a pile of stones,
    seeking to entrench itself among the rocks.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If he is uprooted from his place,
    then it will deny him:
        ‘I never saw you.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Indeed, this is the benefit of God’s way:
    from the soil other plants will sprout.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely God won’t reject those who are blameless
    or hold hands with those who practice evil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will soon fill your mouth with laughter,
    and your lips will shout with joy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who hate you will be clothed with shame,
    and the tent of the wicked will no longer exist.
speaker: Narrator

text: This was Job’s response:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Indeed, I’m fully aware that this is so,
    but how can a person become right with God?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If one were to seek to argue with him,
    he won’t be able to answer him even once in a thousand times.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He is wise in heart and strong in will—
    who can be stubborn against him and succeed?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“He removes mountains without their knowledge,
    overthrowing them in his anger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He shakes the earth from its orbit,
    so that its foundations shudder.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He commands the sun so that it doesn’t shine
    and seals up the stars.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He alone spreads out the heavens,
    he walks on the waves of the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He created Bear, Orion, the Pleiades,
    and the southern constellations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He does great things that cannot be explained,
    and awesome deeds that cannot be counted.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If he were to pass near me, I wouldn’t notice;
    if he moves by, I wouldn’t perceive him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, if he snatches someone away,
    who could restrain him?
        Who can say to him, ‘What are you doing?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“God doesn’t restrain his anger.
    Rahab’s assistants are humiliated under him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So how am I to answer him,
    choosing what I am to say to him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even if I’m in the right,
    I cannot answer him.
        I can only appeal for mercy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Were I to be summoned, and he were to answer me,
    I wouldn’t even believe
        that he was listening to what I have to say.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he crushes me with a storm,
    and keeps on wounding me for no reason.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He won’t let me catch my breath;
    instead, he fills me with bitterness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Is this a contest of strength? He is obviously stronger!
    Is this a matter of justice? Who can sue him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though I’m in the right, my own mouth will condemn me;
    though I’m blameless, he’ll pronounce me as guilty.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
I say it’s all the same—
    he destroys both the blameless and the guilty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If a calamity causes sudden death,
    he’ll mock at the despair of the innocent.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“My days pass faster than a runner;
    but they pass quickly without seeing anything good.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They pass by like a ship made of reeds,
    like an eagle swooping down on its prey.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I were to say, ‘Let me forget my complaint,’
    change the expression on my face, and look cheerful,
speaker: Narrator

text:
then I still dread all of my suffering;
    I know you still won’t acquit me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will be condemned,
    so why should I wear myself out with this futility?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If I wash myself with water from snow,
    and cleanse my hands with lye,
speaker: Narrator

text:
you’ll still drop me into the Pit,
    and my own clothes will despise me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He’s not a man like me,
    so that I can answer him,
        or that we can enter into litigation with one another.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There is not yet a mediator between us,
    who would set his hand on the two of us,
speaker: Narrator

text:
removing his rod from me,
    and not letting terror of him overwhelm me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Otherwise, I would speak without being terrified of him,
    because I’m not like that inside myself.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I am disgusted with living,
    so I’m going to talk about my complaint freely.
        I’ll speak out from the bitterness of my soul.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I’ll say to God,
    ‘Don’t condemn me!
        Let me know why you are fighting me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Does it delight you to oppress
    or despise what you have made,
        while you smile at the plans of the wicked?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you have eyes made of flesh?
    Can you look at things as humans do?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you live only as long as a human being?
    Or live the years of a mortal man?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“‘For you seek out my iniquity
    and search for my sin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Although you know that I’m not guilty,
    there’s no one to deliver me from you!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your hands formed and fashioned me,
    but then you have destroyed me all at once on all sides.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“‘Please remember that you’ve made me like clay
    and you’ll return me to dust.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Didn’t you pour me out like milk
    and let me congeal like cheese?
speaker: Narrator

text:
You covered me with skin and flesh,
    weaving me together with bones and sinews.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You gave life and gracious love to me;
    your providential care has preserved my spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But you’ve hidden these things in your heart—
    I know this was your purpose:
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I sin, you watch me
    and won’t acquit me for my iniquity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“‘Woe to me if I’m guilty!
    If I’m innocent, I cannot lift my head,
because I am filled with disgrace.
    Look at my affliction!
speaker: Narrator

text:
But if I do lift up my head,
    you will hunt me like a lion!
        You will perform miracles in order to fight against me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“‘You have brought new witnesses against me,
    you’re even more angry with me—
        you’ve brought fresh troops to attack me!
speaker: Narrator

text:
So why did you bring me out from the womb?
    I wish I had died, before anyone had seen me,
speaker: Narrator

text:
as if I had never existed;
    carried from the womb to the grave.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My days are so few, aren’t they?
    So leave me alone, then,
        so I can smile a little
speaker: Narrator

text:
before I go, never to return,
    leaving for the land of deep darkness and shadow.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: Zophar from Naamath had this to say:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Shouldn’t a multitude of words be answered,
    or a person who talks too much be vindicated?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will your irrational babble silence people,
    and when you mock them,
        will you escape without being shamed?
speaker: Narrator

text:
You’ve said, ‘My teaching is flawless;
    I’m clean in God’s sight.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But what if God were to speak?
    What if he were to talk with you,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and disclose his wise secrets?
After all, there’s so much more to understanding.
    So be aware that God will exact from you
        less than your sin deserves.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Can you search through God’s complex things?
    Can you uncover the limits of the Almighty?
speaker: Narrator

text:
These things are higher than the heavens,
    so what can you do?
They are deeper than Sheol,
    so what can you know?
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are longer than the earth’s circumference,
    and broader than the ocean.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If he bypasses, or imprisons, or convenes a court,
    who can stop him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he knows mankind’s deceitfulness;
    when he sees iniquity, won’t he himself consider it?
speaker: Narrator

text:
An empty-headed person will gain understanding
    when a wild donkey is born a human being!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Now for you, if you will prepare your heart,
    spread out your hands to him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you have any iniquity, throw it far away.
    Don’t let evil live in your residence.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then your confidence will be flawless,
    and your security will keep you from terror.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You’ll forget your suffering;
    you’ll remember it like water that has evaporated.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your life will be brighter than noonday.
    Even its darkness will be like dawn.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You’ll be secure, because there is hope;
    you’ll see that you’re at rest and safe.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When you sleep, there’ll be nothing to fear;
    and many will court your favor.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: In response Job replied:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Truly, you are the people
    and wisdom will die with you!
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“I’m a laughingstock to my friends,
    someone who called on God.
But then he answered this upright and blameless man,
    and I have become a laughingstock.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The carefree are thinking, ‘I have contempt for misfortune,’
    Those who are about to stumble deserve it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The tents of robbers are at rest,
    and those who provoke God are secure,
        that is, those who carry their god in their pocket.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Ask the wild animals, and they’ll teach you;
    the birds of the sky will tell you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Or ask the green plants of the earth and they’ll teach you;
    let the fish in the sea tell you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who among all of these doesn’t know
    that the Lord’s hand made them,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and that the life of every living thing rests in his control,
    along with the breath of every living human being?
speaker: Narrator

text:
The ear scrutinizes speech
    just as the palate tastes food.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Wisdom may be found in the company of the aged.
    Understanding comes with longevity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
With God is wisdom and strength;
    counsel and understanding belongs to him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When he tears down, nobody rebuilds;
    when he incarcerates, nobody escapes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When he withholds water, rivers dry up;
    when he lets them loose, they’ll flood the land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“With God are strength and sound wisdom;
    both the deceived and those who deceive are responsible to him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He leads counselors away naked;
    he turns judges into fools.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He strips away the authority of kings to punish
    and puts them in prison clothes instead.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He leads away the priests naked
    and overthrows the ruling class.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He keeps reliable advisors from speaking,
    and removes discernment from elders.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He pours contempt on nobles
    and embarrasses the mighty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He uncovers the hidden dimensions from darkness,
    bringing what is in deep shadow to light.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He makes nations great, and then destroys them;
    he enlarges nations, but then sends them away to captivity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He withdraws understanding from national leaders of the world,
    causing them to wander through uncharted wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They grope in the dark without light;
    he causes them to stagger around like a drunkard.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Look, I’ve seen everything;
    I’ve listened carefully and I understand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What you know, I know, too;
    I’m not inferior to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But I want to talk to the Almighty;
    and I’m determined to argue my case before God.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But as for you, you whitewash with lies;
    all of you are worthless quacks.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I wish you’d all just shut up.
    Then at least you would appear to be wise.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Now listen to my dispute!
    Pay attention to my arguments.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why do you speak falsely on God’s behalf
    and speak deceitfully about him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will you show partiality to him?
    Will you plead God’s case?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will things go well for you under his cross-examination?
    Can you lie to him, as you would to a human being?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“He will be sure to rebuke you,
    if you show partiality in secret.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His splendor will petrify you with terror,
    paralyzing you with fear, won’t it?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your maxims are just worthless proverbs;
    your defensive arguments are made of clay.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Don’t talk to me! It’s my turn to speak;
    then whatever happens, happens.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why shouldn’t I bite my flesh
    or take my life in my hands?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even though he kills me,
    I’ll continue to hope in him.
        At least I’ll be able to argue my case to his face!
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have this as my salvation:
    the godless person won’t be appearing before him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pay attention to what I have to say
    and listen to my testimony with your own ears.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Look, now! I’ve prepared my case for court.
    I know that I’m going to win.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who can oppose me?
    If they do, I’ll be silent and die.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Grant me only two things as you deal with me;
    then I won’t hide from you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Withdraw your hand far from me
    and keep me from being petrified with terror.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then call and I’ll answer,
    or let me speak and then you reply to me!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“How many of my iniquities and sins have you counted?
    Show me my transgression and sin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why do you hide your face
    and regard me as your enemy?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Are you a god who would make a leaf tremble
    or who would prosecute a dry straw?
speaker: Narrator

text:
You’ve accused me of bitter things;
    you’ve caused me to reap the sins of my youth.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
So I’m a man who wears out like something rotten,
    like a garment that has become moth-eaten.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Human beings born by women
    are short-lived and full of trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He springs up like a flower and then withers.
    Like a shadow, he disappears and doesn’t last.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, have you opened your eyes on one like this—
    to bring me into a legal fight with you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who can produce a clean thing from an unclean thing?
    No one!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Since his days have been determined,
    the number of his months is known to you.
You’ve set his limit
    and he cannot exceed it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look away from him and leave him alone,
    so he can enjoy his time, like a hired worker.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“There is hope for the tree, if it is cut down,
    that it will sprout again,
        and that its shoots won’t stop growing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even if its roots have grown ancient in the earth,
    and its stump begins to rot in the ground,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the presence of water will make it to bud
    so that it sprouts new branches like a young plant.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But when a person dies and wastes away,
    when a person breathes his last, where will he be?
speaker: Narrator

text:
As water disappears from the sea,
    or water evaporates from a river,
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“Won’t you keep me safe in the afterlife?
    Conceal me until your anger subsides.
Set an appointment for me,
    then remember me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If a human being dies, will he live again?
    I will endure the entire time of my assigned service,
        until I am changed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You’ll call and I’ll answer you;
    you’ll long for your creatures that your hands have made.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then you’ll certainly count every step I took,
    but you won’t keep an inventory of my sin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My transgressions would be sealed up in a bag;
    you would cover over my sins.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Mountains fall and crumble;
    rocks are dislodged from their places.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
You overpower him once and for all, and then he departs;
    you change his appearance and then send him away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If his children are honored, he doesn’t know it;
    if they become insignificant, he never perceives it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He feels only his own pain,
    and grieves only for himself.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Eliphaz from Teman responded:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Should a wise person respond with knowledge based on wind?
    Should he fill his stomach with a wind storm from the east?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Should he engage in unprofitable argument,
    or give a speech that benefits no one?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet you dispense with fear of God
    and hinder meditations before God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Because your sin dictates your speech,
    you have chosen the language of the crafty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your own mouth is condemning you, not I;
    your own lips will testify against you.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Were you the first personto be born?
    Were you brought forth before the hills were made?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have you listened in on God’s secret council?
    Have you limited wisdom only to yourself?
speaker: Narrator

text:
What do you know that we don’t know,
    or that you understand and that isn’t clear to us?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“We have both the gray-haired and the aged with us,
    and they are far older than your father.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Are God’s encouragements inconsequential to you,
    even a word that has been spoken gently to you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why have your emotions carried you away?
    And why do your eyes flash
speaker: Narrator

text:
that you turn your anger against God
    and speak words like this?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“What is mankind, that he can be blameless?
    Or does being born of a woman mean he’ll be in the right?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look, if God doesn’t trust his holy ones,
    if even the heavens aren’t pure as he looks at them,
speaker: Narrator

text:
then how much less is one who is abhorred and corrupted,
    such as a man who drinks injustice like water?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I’ll tell you what, listen to me!
    Let me relate what I’ve seen,
speaker: Narrator

text:
which is what wise men have explained,
    who didn’t withhold anything from their ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text:
To them alone was the land given,
    when no invader passed through their midst.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The wicked person writhes in pain throughout his life,
    a number of years has been reserved for the ruthless.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Terrifying sounds ring in his ears;
    when times are prosperous, the Destroyer will attack him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He does not believe he will escape darkness;
    he is destined for the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He wanders around for food—where is it?
    He knows that a time of darkness is near.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Distress and pressure terrify him;
    they overwhelm him, like a king poised for attack.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“For he has raised his fist against God,
    defying the Almighty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He defiantly ran against him
    carrying his thick, reinforced shield.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though he covered his face with fat,
    and is grossly overweight at the waist,
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will live in devastated towns,
    in abandoned houses
        that are about to become heaps of rubble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“He won’t become rich and his wealth won’t last;
    he won’t expand his holdings to cover the land.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Let him not trust in a worthless speech.
    He leads only himself astray,
        for emptiness will be his reward.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This will be accomplished before his time;
    his branches won’t grow luxuriant.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“He is like a vine that drops its unripe grapes;
    like an olive tree that loses its blossoms.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the company of the godless is desolation,
    and fire consumes the tents of those who bribe.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For they conceive mischief and give birth to iniquity;
    their womb is pregnant with deception.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In response, Job said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I’ve heard many things like this.
    What miserable comforters you all are!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will windy words like yours never end?
    What is upsetting you that you keep on arguing?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I could also talk like you
    if only you were in my place!
Then I would put together an argument against you.
    I would shake my head at you
speaker: Narrator

text:
and encourage you with what I have to say;
    my words of comfort would lessen your pain.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But if I speak, my pain isn’t assuaged;
    if I refrain from speaking, what do I have to lose?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“God has certainly worn me out;
    you devastated my entire world.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You’ve arrested me, making me testify against myself!
    My leanness rises up to attack me, accusing me to my face.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
God has delivered me over to the ungodly,
    throwing me into the control of the wicked.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
Attack follows attack as he breaks through my defenses!
    He runs over me like a mighty warrior.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I’ve even sewn sackcloth directly to my skin;
    I’ve buried my strength in the dust.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My face is red from my tears,
    and dark shadows encircle my eyelids,
speaker: Narrator

text:
even though violence is not my intention,
    and my prayer is pure.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Listen, earth! Don’t cover my blood,
    for my outcry has no place to rest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even now, behold! I have a witness in heaven,
    my Advocate is on high.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My friends mock me,
    while my eyes overflow with tears to God,
speaker: Narrator

text:
crying for him to arbitrate between this man and God;
    as a human being does with his fellow neighbor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For when only a few years have elapsed,
    I’ll start down a path from which I’ll never return.”
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Mockers surround me;
    I cannot stop staring at their hostility all through the night.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Offer, then, some collateral on my behalf.
    Is there anyone who will be my guarantor?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Because you’re the one who closed their hearts to compassion;
    therefore, you won’t let them triumph.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now as for the one who testifies against his friends
    to take their property,
        even the eyes of his children will fail.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“He has made me a byword among people;
    I’m being spit on in the face.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My eyes have grown weak from grief;
    and my whole body is as thin as a shadow.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The upright are appalled over this,
    and the innocent person is troubled by the godless.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the righteous person will hold to his way,
    and those with clean hands will grow stronger and stronger.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Come here now, all of you,
    and I won’t find a wise person among you.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
They have transformed night into day—
    ‘The light,’ they say, ‘is about to become dark.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If my hope were that my house is the afterlife itself,
    if I were to make my bed in darkness,
speaker: Narrator

text:
if I call out to the Pit, ‘You’re my father!’
    or say to the worm, ‘My mother!’ or ‘My sister!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
where would my hope be? 
“And speaking of my hope, who would notice it?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will it go down to the bars that lock the doors of the afterlife?
        Will we descend together into the dust?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Bildad from Shuah replied, saying:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“When are you going to stop your word hunt?
    Think first, and then we can talk.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why do you think we’re like dumb animals?
    Do you think we’re stupid?
speaker: Narrator

text:
You’re tearing yourself to pieces in your anger.
    Will the land be abandoned because of you,
        or the rock be moved from its place?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Indeed, the light of the wicked is extinguished;
    the flame from his fire doesn’t shine.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Light in his tent is dark,
    and his lamp goes out above him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His strong steps are restricted,
    and his own advice trips him up.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“For he has stumbled into a net with his own feet;
    he walked right into the network!
speaker: Narrator

text:
The trap seizes him by the heel;
    a snare tightens its hold on him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A rope lies hidden in the dirt;
    a trap lies waiting for him where he is walking.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“He is petrified by terror that surrounds him on all sides;
    they chase at his heels.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He is starved for strength;
    and is ripe for a fall.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Something gnaws on his skin;
    a deadly disease consumes his limbs.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Torn from the security of his home,
    he is brought before the king of terrors.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“There’s nothing in his tent that belongs to him;
    sulfur is scattered all over his dwelling place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His roots wither underneath,
    while his branches above are being cut off.
speaker: Narrator

text:
No one remembers him anywhere in the land;
    no one names streets in his honor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He is driven away from light to darkness,
    made to wander the landscape.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has no children or descendants within his own people;
    and no survivors where he once lived.
speaker: Narrator

text:
People who live west of him are appalled at his fate;
    those who live east of him are seized with terror.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, the residences of the wicked are like this;
    and so are the homes of those who don’t know God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In response, Job said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“How long do you intend to keep torturing me
    and trying to break me by what you’re saying?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ten times you’ve tried to humiliate me!
    You’re not ashamed to wrong me!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even if it’s true that I’ve erred,
    my error only affects me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you really intend to vaunt yourselves over me,
    and make my problems the basis of your case against me,
speaker: Narrator

text:
then at least you must know that God has accused me of wrong,
    and trapped me with his net.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Although I cried out ‘Violence!’
    I received no answer;
I cried for help,
    but there was no justice.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“He has stripped me of my honor;
    he has stolen the crown off my head!
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
His anger burns against me;
    he regards me as his adversary.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“My brothers are alienated from me;
    my acquaintances are estranged;
speaker: Narrator

text:
my relatives have failed me;
    and my friends have abandoned me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who live in my house—
    and my maidservants, too!—
treat me like a stranger;
    they think I’m a foreigner.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I call to my servant,
    but he doesn’t respond,
        even though I beg to him earnestly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My wife says my breath stinks;
    even my children say I smell bad!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even little children hate me;
    when I get up, they mock me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My closest friends detest me;
    even the ones I love have turned against me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I’m a pile of skin and bones;
    I have barely escaped by the skin of my teeth.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Be gracious to me, be gracious to me, my friends,
    because God’s hand has struck me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why are you chasing me, as God has been doing?
    Aren’t you satisfied that I’m sick?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If only my words were written down;
    if only they were inscribed in a book
speaker: Narrator

text:
using an iron stylus with lead for ink!
