text:
“They listened and waited for me,
    as they remained in silence for my counsel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
After I spoke, they had nothing to say,
    when what I said hit them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They waited for me as one waits for rain,
    as one opens his mouth to drink in a spring rain shower.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I smiled at them when they had no confidence,
    and no one could discourage me.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“But now they mock me;
    men who are far younger than I,
whose fathers I would have hated
    to entrust with my own sheep dogs.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Furthermore, what could I have gained
    from men whose strength is gone?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Unproductive due to poverty and hunger,
    they could only scratch in parched soil,
        devastated and desolated.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“They would pluck off herbs from salt marshes to eat;
    and roots of the broom shrub for food.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Driven away from human company,
    they were shouted at as though they were thieves.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They lived in the most dangerous of ravines,
    in holes in the ground, and among rocks.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They bray like donkeys among the bushes
    and huddle together under the desert weeds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sons of fools and of uncertain reputation,
    they have been driven from the land by scourging.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Now, I’ve become the object of their mocking melodies;
    I’m nothing but a fool’s proverb to them!
speaker: Narrator

text:
They abhor me—they keep their distance from me;
    but they don’t refrain from spitting at the sight of me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But God has loosened his cord and afflicted me;
    so they’ve cast off all restraints in my presence.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
They come like those who breach through a wall;
    as everything crashes around me they’ll roll on and on!
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“Now, my soul pours itself out;
    the time of my affliction has taken control of me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The night racks my bones;
    and the pain that gnaws on me will not rest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My clothes are disheveled by his forceful treatment of me;
    he restricts my movement like the collar of my cloak.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“He tossed me into the mire;
    I’ve become like dust and ashes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I cry for help to you,
    but you won’t answer me;
I stand still,
    but you only look at me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You changed toward me, and now you’re cruel to me;
    with your mighty hand you are persecuting me;
speaker: Narrator

text:
you carried me off in a wind storm,
    making me ride on it
        while you toss me about as the storm roars around me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I know that you’re about to kill me,
    so I’m about to go to the house that’s appointed for all the living.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Surely he won’t stretch his hand against the needy, will he,
    especially if they cry to him in their calamity?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Haven’t I wept for the one who is going through hard times?
    Haven’t I grieved for the needy?
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have hoped for good, but evil came instead;
    I have hoped for light, but darkness came.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I’m boiling mad inside, and I won’t remain silent;
    the time for my affliction to confront me has arrived.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“In growing darkness, I walked without sunlight;
    I stood in the congregation to cry for help.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I’ve become a brother to jackals,
    and a friend to ostriches.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My skin turns black all over me;
    and my bones seem burned from the heat.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But my harp is in mourning;
    my flute plays only songs for those who are weeping.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I made a covenant with my eyes;
    how, then, can I focus my attention on a virgin?
speaker: Narrator

text:
What would I have from God above,
    what heritage from the Almighty on high,
speaker: Narrator

text:
if not calamity that is due the unjust,
    and misfortune that is due those who practice iniquity?
speaker: Narrator

text:
He watches my life,
    observing every one of my actions, does he not?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If I’ve lived my life in the company of vanity,
    or run quickly to embrace deception,
speaker: Narrator

text:
let my righteousness be weighed in honest scales,
    and God will make known my integrity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I have stepped away from the way,
    or if my heart covets whatever my eyes see,
        or if some other blemish clings to my hands,
speaker: Narrator

text:
what I’ve planted, let another eat
    or let my crops be uprooted.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If my heart has been seduced by a woman
    and I’ve laid in wait at my friend’s door,
speaker: Narrator

text:
then let my wife cook for another person
    and may someone else sleep with her,
speaker: Narrator

text:
because something as lascivious as that
    is an iniquity that should be judged.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The fires of Abaddon will burn,
    disrupting every part of my eternal reward.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If I’ve refused to help my male and female servants
    when they complain against me,
speaker: Narrator

text:
what will I do when God stands up to act?
    When he asks the questions, how will I answer him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
The one who made me in the womb made them, too, didn’t he?
    Didn’t the same one prepare each of us in the womb?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If I refused to grant the desire of the poor
    or exhausted the eyes of the widow,
speaker: Narrator

text:
if I ate my meals by myself
    without feeding orphans,
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
if I’ve observed someone who is about to die for lack of clothes
    or if I have no clothing to give to the poor,
speaker: Narrator

text:
if he hadn’t thanked me from the bottom of his heart,
    if he had not been warmed by wool from my sheep,
speaker: Narrator

text:
if I’ve raised my hand against an orphan
    when I thought I would against him in court,
speaker: Narrator

text:
then let my arm fall from its socket;
    and may my arm be torn off at the shoulder.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For I’m terrified of what calamity God may have in store for me;
    and I cannot endure his grandeur.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If I’ve put my confidence in gold,
    if I’ve told gold, ‘You’re my security,’
speaker: Narrator

text:
if I’ve found joy in great wealth that I own,
    if I’ve earned a lot with my own hands,
speaker: Narrator

text:
if I look at the sun when it shines
    or the moon as it rises in steady splendor,
speaker: Narrator

text:
so that in the depths of my deceived heart
    I worshipped them with my mouth and hands,
speaker: Narrator

text:
this is also a sin that deserves to be judged,
    since I would have tried to deceive God above.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Have I rejoiced in the destruction of those who hate me,
    or have I been happy that evil caught up with him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
No, I haven’t allowed my mouth to sin
    by asking for his life with a curse.
speaker: Narrator

text:
People in my household have said,
    ‘We cannot find anyone who has not been satisfied with his meat,’ haven’t they?
speaker: Narrator

text:
No stranger ever spent the night in the street,
    because I opened my doors to travelers.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Have I covered my transgression like other people,
    to conceal iniquity within myself?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have I feared large crowds?
    Has my family’s contempt ever terrified me
        so that I remained silent and wouldn’t go outside?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Who will grant me a hearing?
    Here’s my signature—let the Almighty answer!
Since my adversary indicted me,
speaker: Narrator

text:
I’ll wear it on my shoulder,
        or tie it on my head for a crown!
speaker: Narrator

text:
I’ll give an account for every step I’ve taken;
    I’ll approach him confidently like a Commander-in-Chief.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If my land were to cry out against me
    or if all its furrows wept as one,
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I’ve consumed its produce without paying for it
    and snuffed out the life of its owners;
speaker: Narrator

text:
may thorns spring up instead of wheat,
    and obnoxious weeds instead of barley.”
With this, Job’s discourse with his friends is completed.
speaker: Narrator

text: These three men stopped responding to Job, because he was claiming to be righteous, in his own opinion.
speaker: Narrator

text: But then Barachel’s son Elihu from Buz, one of Ram’s descendants, got really angry. He was furious with Job because he had been declaring himself righteous instead of vindicating God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Furthermore, he was furious with his three friends because they had not answered Job, but instead had condemned him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elihu waited to have a word with Job, since the others were older than he,
speaker: Narrator

text: but when he saw that there had been no response from those three, he got even more angry.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Barachel’s son Elihu from Buz responded and said:
“I’m younger than you are.
    Because you’re older, I was terrified
        to tell you what I know.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I thought, experience should speak;
    abundance of years teaches wisdom.
speaker: Narrator

text:
However, a spirit exists in mankind,
    and the Almighty’s breath gives him insight.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The aged aren’t always wise,
    nor do the elderly always understand justice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore I’m saying, ‘Listen to me!’
    Then I’ll declare what I know.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Look! I have waited to hear your speech,
    so I listened to your insights
        while you searched for the right words to say.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, I paid close attention to you all,
    but none of you were able to refute Job
        or answer his arguments convincingly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“So that you cannot claim, ‘We have found wisdom!’
    let God do the rebuking, not man;
speaker: Narrator

text:
let him not direct a rebuke toward me.
    I won’t be responding to him with your arguments.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Job’s friends won’t reason with him anymore;
    discouraged, words escape them.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“I will contribute my arguments as an answer;
    I’ll declare what I know,
speaker: Narrator

text:
because I’m filled with things to say,
    and my spirit within me compels me to speak.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My insides feel like unvented wine,
    like it’s about to burst like a new wineskin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Let me speak! I need relief!
    Let me open my lips and respond.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I won’t discriminate against anyone,
    and I won’t flatter any person,
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“Now please listen to what I have to say, Job.
    Listen to every word!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look! I’ve begun to speak,
    and I’m fashioning my words.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I speak from the innocence of my heart;
    and my lips will utter what I sincerely know.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The spirit of God fashioned me;
    and the breath of the Almighty gives me life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Answer me, if you can!
    Present your case! Take your stand in my presence!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look! As far as God is concerned, I’m just like you are—
    I, too, have been pinched off from a piece of clay.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t be afraid of me;
    I’ll go easy on you.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You spoke clearly so I could hear;
    I’ve heard what you’ve said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘I’m pure. I’m without sin;
    I’m innocent. I’m harboring no iniquity inside of me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Nevertheless, God has found a pretext to attack me;
    he considers me his enemy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has bound my feet in shackles,
    and keeps watching everything I do.’”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You aren’t right about this;
    My response is that God is greater than human beings.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why are you arguing with him?
    He doesn’t have to give explanations for what he does to you!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“God speaks time and time again—
    but nobody notices—
speaker: Narrator

text:
in a dream or night vision,
    when a deep sleep falls on mankind
        while they sleep on their beds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
That’s when he opens the ear of mankind,
    authenticating his messages to them,
speaker: Narrator

text:
turning a person from his actions,
    keeping him from pride,
speaker: Narrator

text:
sparing his soul from the Pit
    and his life from violent death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“He is being reproved by painful bed rest,
    with continual aching in his bones.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He cannot stand his food,
    and he has no desire for appetizing food.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His flesh wastes away;
    his bones, which once couldn’t be seen, are visible.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His soul is getting close to the Pit;
    his life is approaching its executioner.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If there’s a messenger appointed to mediate for Job
    —one out of a thousand—
        to represent the man’s integrity on his behalf,
speaker: Narrator

text:
to show favor to him and to plead,
    ‘Deliver him from having to go down to the Pit—
        I know where his ransom is!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let his flesh be rejuvenated as he was in his youth!
    Let him recover the strength of his youth.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“He’ll sing to mankind with these words: 
‘I’ve sinned. I have twisted what is right.
    Yet he has not repaid me like I deserve.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has redeemed my soul from going down to the Pit;
    my life will see the light.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed God does all these things
    again and again with a person
speaker: Narrator

text:
to bring back his soul from the Pit;
    to light him with the light of life.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Job, pay attention! Listen to me!
    Be silent and let me speak.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you have anything to say, answer me;
    speak up, because I’d be happy to vindicate you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But if you have nothing to say, then at least listen to me!
    Be quiet and learn some wisdom from me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elihu continued speaking, and said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Listen to what I have to say, you wise men!
    Pay attention to me, you educated people!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Since the ear tests words
    like a palate tastes food,
speaker: Narrator

text:
let’s choose what’s right for us.
    Let’s consider among ourselves what is good.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now this is Job’s claim: 
‘Even though I’m innocent,
    God has stopped treating me righteously.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have I lied concerning the justice that I deserve?
    My wound is incurable,
        though transgression cannot be attributed to me.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“What man is like Job,
    who drinks mockery like water,
speaker: Narrator

text:
traffics in those who practice evil,
    and walks with wicked people?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Because he says, ‘There’s no profit
    for a man to find joy with God.’”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Therefore you men of understanding, listen to me!
    Far be it for God to practice wickedness,
        or the Almighty to do what is wrong,
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Truly, God doesn’t practice wickedness,
    and the Almighty doesn’t pervert justice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who entrusted the earth to him?
    Who made him responsible for the entire inhabited world?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If he were to decide to do so,
    that is, to take back to himself his spirit and breath of life,
speaker: Narrator

text:
every living thing would die all at once,
    and mankind would return to dust.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you have understanding, listen to this!
    Pay attention to what I have to say:
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can one who hates justice really govern?
    And if God is righteous and mighty, can you condemn him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can one say to a king, ‘You’re vile!’
    or to nobles, ‘You’re wicked!’?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who isn’t partial to princes?
    Who doesn’t give preference to the nobles over the poor?
        Nevertheless, all of them are his handiwork.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Yes, Job, his eyes constantly watch the behavior of human beings;
    he carefully observes their every step.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There’s no such thing as darkness to him—
    not even deep darkness—
        that can conceal those who practice evil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He won’t examine mankind further,
    that they would go before God to judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He shatters valiant men without a need to investigate,
    and he raises others in their place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thus he acknowledges their behavior, and overcomes them;
    when night time comes, they are crushed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“He strikes the wicked among them
    in a place where they can be seen
speaker: Narrator

text:
because they’ve abandoned their pursuit of him
    and had no respect for any of his ways.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As a result, the cries of the poor have reached him
    and he has heard the cry of the afflicted.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If he remains silent, who will condemn him?
    If he conceals his face, who can see him?
        He watches over both nation and individual alike,
speaker: Narrator

text:
to keep the godless man from reigning
    or laying a snare for the people.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Has anyone ever really told God,
    ‘I’ve endured, and I won’t act corruptly anymore.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What I don’t see, instruct me!
    If I’ve done anything evil, I won’t repeat it!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Should you not be paid back,
    since you have rejected him?
You do the choosing! I won’t!
    Tell us what you know!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Men of understanding, speak to me!
    Are any of you men wise? Then listen to me!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Job has been speaking from his own ignorance,
    and what he has to say lacks insight!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Oh, how Job needs to be given a full court trial,
    as a rebuke to those who practice evil,
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: In response, Elihu said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Are you saying that it’s just for you to claim,
    ‘I’m more righteous than God?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
After all, you’ve asked what your benefit will be:
    ‘What will I profit from refraining from sin?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
I’m going to respond to that statement,
    and to your friends with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Observe the heavens! Take a look around!
    Look! The clouds are higher than you, aren’t they?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you sin, what will that do to harm him?
    If you add transgression to transgression
        what will it do to him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you are righteous, what will you add to him?
    What can God receive from your efforts?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your wickedness affects only yourself;
    and your righteousness, only human beings.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“They cry out because they have many oppressors;
    they cry for help because the powerful are abusing them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He never asks, ‘Where is God, my Creator,
    who gives me songs in the night,
speaker: Narrator

text:
who teaches us more than the earth’s wild animals,
    and makes us wiser than the birds of the sky?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“They cry out there, but he doesn’t answer
    because of the arrogance of those who practice evil.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Even though you complain that you can’t perceive him,
    your case is already pending for judgment in his presence
        so keep on placing your hope in him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“So now, if he doesn’t inflict punishment in his anger,
    then he doesn’t keep track of your many transgressions.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When he began speaking, he communicated only worthlessness;
    he added words upon words without knowing anything.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elihu responded again and said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Be patient with me a moment longer,
    and I’ll show you that there’s more to say on God’s behalf.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I’ll take what I know to its logical conclusion
    and ascribe righteousness to my Creator,
speaker: Narrator

text:
because what I have to say isn’t deceptive,
    and the one who has perfect knowledge is with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Indeed God is mighty and he doesn’t show disrespect;
    he is mighty and strong of heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He doesn’t let the wicked live;
    he grants justice to the afflicted.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“If they’re bound in chains,
    caught in ropes of affliction,
speaker: Narrator

text:
he’ll reveal their actions to them,
    when their transgressions have become excessive.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He opens their ears and instructs them,
    commanding them to repent from evil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If they listen and serve him,
    they’ll finish their lives in prosperity
        and their years will be pleasant.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But if they won’t listen,
    they’ll perish by the sword
        and die in their ignorance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The godless at heart cherish anger;
    they won’t cry out for help when God afflicts them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They die in their youth;
    and their life will end among temple prostitutes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He’ll deliver the afflicted through their afflictions
    and open their ears when they are oppressed.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Indeed, he drew you away from the brink of distress
    to a spacious place without constraints,
        filling your festive table with bountiful food.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But now you are occupied with the case of the wicked;
    but justice and judgment will be served.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So that no one entices you with riches,
    don’t let a large ransom turn you astray.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Will your wealth sustain you when you’re in distress,
    despite your most powerful efforts?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t long for night,
    when people vanish in their place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Be careful! Don’t turn to evil,
    because of this you will be tried by more than affliction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Indeed, God is exalted in his power.
    Who is like him as a teacher?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who ordained his path for him,
    and who has asked him, ‘You are wrong, aren’t you?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Remember to magnify his awesome activities,
    about which mortal man has sung.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All of mankind sees him;
    human beings observe him from afar off.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“God is truly awesome, beyond what we know;
    the number of his years is unknowable.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He draws up drops of water,
    distilling it to rain and mist.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the clouds pour down;
    they drop their rain on all of humanity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Furthermore, can anyone understand cloud patterns,
    or the thundering in his pavilion?
speaker: Narrator

text:
He scatters his lightning above it,
    and covers the bottom of the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He uses them to judge some people
    and give food to many.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His hands are covered with lightning
    that he commands to strike his designated target.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His thunder declares his presence;
    and tells the animals what is coming.”
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Listen carefully to his thundering voice;
    to the sound that rumbles from his mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He releases his lightning throughout the sky,
    to the ends of the earth.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“God thunders with his wondrous voice;
    he does awesome works that we don’t comprehend.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he says to the snow, ‘Fall to the earth.’
    He tells the rain, ‘Pour down,’
        then it rains profusely.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“He puts a limit to the skill of every person;
    to delineate all people from what they do.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Then a beast enters its lair
    and remains in its den.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“From the south, a whirlwind proceeds,
    out of the icy north winds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the breath of God ice is produced,
    and a wide body of water is frozen.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He also loads the clouds with moisture,
    scattering his lightning with the clouds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It whirls about in circles at his direction
    to accomplish all that he commands
        throughout the surface of the entire world,
speaker: Narrator

text:
whether for discipline on his land
    or to demonstrate his gracious love,
        he causes it to be realized.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Pay attention to this, Job!
    Stand still,
        and consider the wondrous attributes of God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you know how God ordains them,
    and makes his lightning to flash throughout his clouds?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you understand his wondrous work of balancing the clouds,
    the one whose knowledge is perfect,
speaker: Narrator

text:
you whose garments are hot,
    even though the land is cooled by a south wind?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you spread out the skies like he does;
    can you cast them as one might a mirror?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Tell us! What are we to say to him?
    Can we prepare our case to face him
        when our faces are in darkness?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Has it been relayed to God that I want to talk?
    Can a person speak when he is confused?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“So then, the sun is too bright to gaze at, is it not?
    The sky is swept clean by the wind that blows, is it not?
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the north he brings gold;
    around God is awesome splendor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We cannot find the Almighty—
    he is majestic in power and justice,
and overflowing with righteousness;
    he never oppresses.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore humanity fears him,
    which none of the wise can quite comprehend.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord responded to Job from the whirlwind and said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Who is this who keeps darkening my counsel
    without knowing what he’s talking about?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Stand up like a man!
    I’ll ask you some questions,
        and you give me some answers!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Where were you when I laid the foundation of my earth?
    Tell me, since you’re so informed!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who set its measurement? Am I to assume you know?
    Who stretched a boundary line over it?
speaker: Narrator

text:
On what were its bases set?
    Who laid its corner stone
speaker: Narrator

text:
while the morning stars sang together
    and all the divine beings shouted joyfully?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Who enclosed the sea with limits
    when it gushed out of the womb,
speaker: Narrator

text:
when I made clouds to be its clothes
    and thick darkness its swaddling blanket,
speaker: Narrator

text:
when I proscribed a boundary for it,
    set in place bars and doors for it;
speaker: Narrator

text:
and said, ‘You may come only this far and no more.
    Your majestic waves will stop here.’?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Have you ever commanded the morning at any time during your life?
    Do you know where the dawn lives,
speaker: Narrator

text:
where it seizes the edge of the earth
    and shakes the wicked out of it?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like clay is molded by a signet ring,
    the earth’s hills and valleys then stand out
        like the colors of a garment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then from the wicked their light is withheld
    and their upraised arm is broken.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Have you been to the source of the sea
    and walked about in the recesses of the deepest ocean?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have the gates of death been revealed to you?
    Have you seen the gates of the deepest darkness?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you understand the breadth of the earth?
    Tell me, since you know it all!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Where is the road to where the light lives?
    Or where does the darkness live?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you take it to its homeland,
    since you know the path to his house?
speaker: Narrator

text:
You should know! After all, you had been born back then,
    so the number of your days is great!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Have you entered the storehouses of the snow
    or seen where the hail is stored,
speaker: Narrator

text:
which I’ve reserved for the tribulation to come,
    for the day of battle and war?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Where is the lightning diffused
    or the east wind scattered around the earth?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Who cuts canals for storm floods,
    and paths for the lightning and thunder,
speaker: Narrator

text:
to bring rain upon a land without inhabitants,
    a desert in which no human beings live,
speaker: Narrator

text:
to satisfy a desolate and devastated desert,
    causing it to sprout vegetation?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Does the rain have a father?
    Who fathered the dew?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whose womb brings forth the ice?
    Who gives birth to frost out of an empty sky,
speaker: Narrator

text:
when water solidifies like stone
    and the surface of the deepest sea freezes?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Can you bind the chains of Pleiades
    or loosen the cords of Orion?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you bring out constellations in their season?
    Can you guide the Bear with her cubs?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you know the laws of the heavens?
    Can you regulate their authority over the earth?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Can you call out to the clouds,
    so that abundant water drenches you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you command the lightning,
    so that it goes forth and calls to you, ‘Look at us!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Who sets wisdom within you,
    or imbues your mind with understanding?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who has the wisdom to be able to count the clouds,
    or to empty the water jars of heaven,
speaker: Narrator

text:
when dust dries into a mass
    and then breaks apart into clods?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Can you hunt prey for the lioness
    to satisfy young lions
speaker: Narrator

text:
when they crouch in their dens
    and lie in ambush in their lairs?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who prepares food for the raven,
    when its offspring cry out to God
        as they wander for lack of food?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Do you know when the mountain goat gives birth?
    Do you watch the doe as it calves its young?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you count the months of their gestation?
    Do you know the time when they give birth,
speaker: Narrator

text:
when they crouch down to give birth to their offspring,
    and let go of their birth pangs?
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“Who sets the wild donkey free?
    Who loosens the bonds of the wild donkey
speaker: Narrator

text:
to whom I’ve given the Arabah for a home;
    the salt plain for his dwelling place?
speaker: Narrator

text:
He despises city noises;
    he ignores the shouts of the driver.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He ranges the mountains that are his pasture
    to search for anything green.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is the wild ox willing to serve you?
    Will he sleep at night near your feeding trough?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you bind the ox to plow a furrow with a rope?
    Will he harrow after you in the valley?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will you trust him because of his great strength
    and entrust your labor to him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will you trust him that he’ll bring in your grain,
    and gather it to your threshing floor?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The wings of the ostrich flap joyously,
    but aren’t its pinions and feathers like the stork?
speaker: Narrator

text:
She abandons her eggs on the ground
    and lets them be warmed in the sand,
speaker: Narrator

text:
but she forgets that a foot might crush them
    or any wild animal might trample them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She mistreats her young as though they’re not hers,
    and she has no fear that her labor may be in vain,
speaker: Narrator

text:
because God didn’t grant her wisdom
    and never gave her understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And yet when she gets ready to run,
    she laughs at the horse and its rider.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you instill the horse with strength?
    Do you clothe its neck with a mane?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you make him leap like the locust,
    and make the splendor of his snorting terrifying?
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
A quiver of arrows rattles against his side,
    along with a flashing spear and a lance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Leaping in his excitement, he takes in the ground;
    he cannot stand still when the trumpets sound!
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the trumpet blasts he’ll neigh, ‘Aha! Aha!’
    From a distance he can sense war,
        the war cry of generals, and their shouting.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Is it by your understanding that the hawk flies,
    spreading its wings toward the south?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Does the eagle soar high at your command
    and build its nest on the highest crags?
speaker: Narrator

text:
He dwells on the crags where he makes his home,
    there on the rocky crag is his stronghold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From there he searches for prey,
    and his eyes recognize it from a distance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His young ones feast on blood;
    he’ll be found wherever there’s a carcass.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord continued his response to Job by saying:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Should the one who is fighting the Almighty find fault with him?
    Let God’s accuser answer.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job replied to the Lord. He said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I must look insignificant to you!
    How can I answer you?
        I’m speechless.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I spoke once,
    but I can’t answer;
I tried a second time,
    but I won’t do so anymore.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord answered Job from the wind storm and told him:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Stand up like a man!
    I’ll ask you some questions,
        and you give me some answers!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed would you annul my justice and condemn me,
    just so you can claim that you’re righteous?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you have strength like God?
    Can you create thunder with a sound like he can?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“When you have adorned yourself with exalted majesty,
    clothed yourself with splendor and dignity,
speaker: Narrator

text:
dispensed the fury of your anger,
    made sure that you have humbled every proud person,
speaker: Narrator

text:
stared down and subdued every proud person,
    trampled the wicked right where they are,
speaker: Narrator

text:
buried them in the dust together,
    and sent them bound to that secret place,
speaker: Narrator

text:
then I will applaud you myself!
    I’ll admit that you can deliver yourself by your own efforts!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Please observe Behemoth, which I made along with you.
    He eats grass like an ox.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now take a look at the strength that he has in his loins,
    and in the muscles of his abdomen.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His tail protrudes stiffly, like cedar;
    the sinews of his thigh interlink for strength.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His bones are conduits of bronze;
    his strong bones are like bars of iron.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He is the grandest of God’s undertakings,
    yet his creator is approaching him with his sword.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Mountains produce food for him,
    where all the wild animals frolic.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He lies under the lotus trees,
    hiding under reeds and marshes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The lotus trees cover him with their shade,
    and willows that line the wadis surround him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What you see as a raging river doesn’t alarm him;
    he is confident when the Jordan overflows.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Are your eyes looking to capture him,
    or to pierce his snout with a bridle?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Can you draw Leviathan out of the water with a hook,
    or tie down his tongue with a rope?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you attach a bridle to his snout,
    or pierce his jaw with a hook?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will he make many supplications to you,
    or will he beg you for mercy?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will he try to make a deal with you,
    so that you may take him in servitude forever?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Will you play with him like a pet bird?
    Will you put a leash on him for your little girls?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will your business be able to buy him,
    Will you divide him among your merchant friends?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will you fill his flesh with harpoons,
    or his head with lances?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lay your hand on him,
    and you’ll remember the struggle.
        You’ll never do that again!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Look! Anyone’s hope to capture him will prove itself false;
    anyone would be terrified just by looking at him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
No one is fierce enough to dare to arouse him.
“Who, then, can stand in my presence and face me?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who can take me to court and be reconciled to me?
        All of heaven is mine.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I won’t be silent concerning his limbs,
    his mighty strength, and orderly frame.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who can strip off his outer armor?
    Who can approach him with a bridle?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who dares to open his mouth,
    since it is ringed with his terrible teeth!
speaker: Narrator

text:
His protective scales are his pride,
    they lie sealed tightly together.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Each one is so close to the other
    that not even air comes in between them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Each is attached to the other,
    grasping each other so they cannot be separated.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“His snorting releases flashes of light;
    his eyes are like the rays of the dawn.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Flames blaze from his mouth;
    streams of sparking fire fly out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Smoke billows from his nostrils;
    like a boiling pot or burning reeds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His breath can ignite coal;
    and flames proceed from his mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“His neck is so powerful
    that all who meet him are terrified.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There is no flaw in his body’s armor;
    it is firmly fixed on him and unbreachable.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His heart is as strong as stone,
    it is as hard as a lower millstone.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When he rears up, the mighty are terrified;
    they are bewildered as he thrashes about.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Thrusting at him with a sword won’t be effective,
    nor will spears, darts, or javelins.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He regards iron like straw,
    and hardened bronze like a dead tree.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Arrows won’t make him flee;
    stones from a sling are only pebbles to him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Clubs are like twigs;
    he laughs at the whoosh of the javelin.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
He causes the deep to boil like water in a pot,
    and churns the sea like one stirs ointment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sea is luminescent behind him;
    his wake turns the sea white, like those with gray hair.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“There’s nothing like him on earth;
    he was created without the ability to fear.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He looks down on everything that is high;
    he rules over every kind of pride.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Job replied to the Lord:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I know that you can do anything
    and nothing that you plan is impossible.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You asked, ‘Who is this that darkens counsel without knowledge?’
    Well now, I have talked about what I don’t understand—
        awesome things beyond me that I don’t know.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen now, and I will speak for myself;
    I’ll interrogate you and then inform me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I’ve heard you with my ears;
    and now I’ve seen you with my eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As a result, I despise myself and repent
    in dust and ashes.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After these words had been spoken by the Lord to Job, the Lord spoke to Eliphaz from Teman: “My anger is burning against you along with your two friends, since you haven’t spoken correctly about me, as did my servant Job.
speaker: Narrator

text: So take seven bulls and seven rams and bring them to my servant Job. And bring a whole burnt offering for yourselves and my servant Job will pray for you. I’ll encourage him by not responding as your disgraceful folly deserves, since you didn’t speak about me correctly as did my servant Job.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Eliphaz from Teman, Bildad from Shuah, and Zophar from Naamath did precisely as the Lord had spoken to them, because the Lord showed favor to Job.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord restored Job’s prosperity after he prayed for his friends. The Lord doubled everything that Job had once possessed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all his brothers and sisters and all those who knew him before arrived. They ate food with him in his house, mourned for him, and consoled him for all the trouble that the Lord had brought and placed on him. Some gave him gold bullion and some brought gold earrings.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord blessed Job during the latter part of his life more than the former, since he owned 14,000 sheep, 6,000 camels, 1,000 teams of oxen and 1,000 female donkeys.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also had seven sons and three daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: He named the first daughter Jemima, the second Keziah, and the name of the third was Keren-happuch.
speaker: Narrator

text: No one could find more beautiful women in the whole land than Job’s daughters. Their father gave them their inheritance along with their brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Job lived 140 years after this, and saw his children and grandchildren to the fourth generation.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job died at an old age, having lived a full life.
speaker: Narrator
